entry.title: Production Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MPS Planning Results [Part 2]
entry.content:
[Blog Type: Hands-on Expertise]

[Blog Series: In the previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results [Part 1], the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor focused on MRP products (purchasing product and intermediate product) was illustrated, while on this blog post the MPS Production Planning Monitor focused on MPS products (final product) is explained.]

 

Summary

This blog post describes how to build a planning monitoring tool to evaluate and manage the MPS results for multiple materials. This tool can show per material the historical consumption data ‚Äì consumption-based planning ‚Äì together with the stocks and requirements information ‚Äì material requirements planning ‚Äì, and the corresponding MRP created receipt elements to cover the shortages.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on the visualization of the MRP results.

 

Introduction

A typical customer requirement is to visualize the result of the MRP run for several materials in a report format, that is, they want MD04 for every material on a plant in a single screen. The purpose is to have an easy and fast way of identification of critical materials where the planner needs to take an action, and then being able to select the specific material and drill down into the stock, requirements and planning elements details. There is not a standard report available that would show a detailed display of stock/requirements list for multiple materials.

A collective MRP results view is normally something very difficult to build, as companies have thousands of materials per plant with different business cases concerning procurement types, planning strategies, production types, origin of the requirements, etc‚Ä¶ Furthermore, the target information to be displayed is different depending on the user role:

  • As a production supervisor, buyer, sales executive or MRP controller, you want to access information on the stock/requirements situation of the material, and then gain an overview of the development of stock and requirements in the coming weeks.
  • As a production supervisor, you want to gain an overview of the MRP elements for in-house production (planned orders, production orders, dependent reservations) or of the MRP elements for a particular production line.
  • As a buyer, you want to check which purchase orders and purchase requisitions exist for a material for a particular vendor.
  • As a sales executive, you are only interested in the current sales orders for a particular customer for a material.
  • As an MRP controller, you are interested in available quantities based on sales orders that have actually been received and not on the basis of the planned independent requirements. You therefore want the planned independent requirements to be displayed, but do not want to change the available quantity if sales order exists.
  • As an MRP controller, you want to be informed about the requirements of bulk materials or materials that are planned using consumption-based planning, to check whether these requirements occur continually.

Another issue to consider is the requirement of some customers to manage historical consumption data together with the requirements information, thus allowing them to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same periods in the same single screen.

Therefore, having all these requirements and conditions in mind, we may think that building a collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials becomes a great challenge. This blog explains how this collective planning tool can be built for isolated and specific planning scenarios.

 

Evaluating the Planning Run on SAP S/4HANA

For Classic MRP, the available tools for checking the planning results are the following:

  • Stock/Requirements List
  • MRP List
  • Evaluation of the Planning Situation
  • Evaluation of the Planning Result
  • Planning Table for repetitive manufacturing

During the planning run, the system analyzes the requirements that exist for the planned materials and creates procurement or manufacturing elements to cover these requirements. The evaluations on these tools show all receipt and issue elements for a material in tabular form and enable you to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements situation for the material as well as to branch into the processing function for the MRP elements for this material.

In the stock/requirements list, the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation is displayed. Changes that are made after the planning date are displayed directly, so the list is dynamic. The MRP list always displays the stock/requirements situation at the time of the last planning run. Changes that are made after the planning date are not taken into consideration, so the list is static.

The planning situation takes all changes in stock, receipts and issues that occur between planning runs into account (as in the stock/requirements list). The planning result displays the result of the last planning run (as in the MRP list). The main difference is that you set up a special evaluation layout for the formatting of the data in the planning result and planning situation. This layout defines which receipt and issue elements are displayed at which level of aggregation.

In SAP S/4HANA, the MRP Live is used, and we also have the MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps and the MPR Situation Handling. MRP Lists are gone with MRP Live due to the considerable performance improvement. The several available MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps display an overview of materials with possible stock shortages, and you can also drill down into a specific material to see the stock/requirements situation.

The new Fiori Apps for MRP evaluation are more visually appealing, and they contain features only available in Fiori, such as Demand-Driven MRP (DDMRP) and Predictive MRP (pMRP). Moreover, they are also supported in mobile devices.

On below table you can find a summary of the abovementioned MRP transactions or Fiori Apps:

Application

Description

Transaction MD04

Display Individual Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD07

Display Collective Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD05

Individual Display of MRP List

Transaction MD06

Collective Display of MRP List

Transaction MD44

Planning Situation

Transaction MD47

Collective Display for Planning Situation

Transaction MD45

Planning Result

Transaction MD46

Collective Display for Planning Result

Transaction MD48

Multi-Plant Planning Situation

Fiori App F0251A

Manage Material Coverage

Fiori App F2101A

Monitor Material Coverage

 

Customer Requirement for a Collective Evaluation of the MRP Planning Results

Customer business case was a small-sized food company with mainly a mass production environment using discrete manufacturing. Main finished products were fresh products sent to retailers to be sold on the supermarket‚Äôs shelf. Therefore, demand was seasonal but also with a special focus on daily consumption pattern.  The customer was interested on running the MRP with requirements based on forecast demand, but also considering the historical consumption of the last four weeks per day, to have the whole picture.

Since it was just a small company, there were only two main MRP responsible for the whole of the planning process and availability control for purchasing products, intermediate production and final product production. The two main areas of responsibility were MPS products, covering the final products to sale, and MRP products, covering the products for purchasing and intermediate production. On this blog we will focus on the MPS products; the MRP products were already covered on previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results.

The customer used a make-to-stock production (goods sold from stock) because of the following reasons:

  • The materials were produced independently of the sales orders.
  • The materials were not assigned to specific sales orders (not segregated).
  • Costs were required to be tracked at material level, and not at sales order level.

The main objective was to quickly provide the clients with goods from the stock. The main constraint was that real sales orders were often received from clients only for one day, and normally with just one day in advance or even the same day. Therefore, customer needed to produce goods without having the sales orders, as expecting the clients demand in future.

On this make-to-stock scenario, to avoid unreasonably high stock levels, a production plan is created in advance, and then you decide whether sales orders exceeding your plan are to affect production or not. Receiving sales orders as early as possible (using scheduling agreements, for example) also contributes to minimize high stock levels, but it was unrealistic on this customer, so a smooth demand forecast was key.

The production was determined by a production plan based on demand forecast (demand management), and only sales orders for first day exceeding the plan directly influenced production. If available, sales order information for subsequent days was required to be displayed for information purposes only (as normally info was uncompleted), but forecast was the demand driver except for the first day. Therefore, planning strategy used was net requirements planning on plant level (strategy 10), which allows to smooth the demand program.

Other very important considerations of the customer for achieving an effective materials planning were the following:

  • Customer wanted to expedite material planning with a more detailed collective material overview than the one provided by standard SAP S/4HANA MRP apps.
  • Customer requested to analyze materials on a dynamic periodic basis, mainly daily, but also weekly and monthly. The operative planning is usually managed by day, meanwhile medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.
  • Customer requested a calculation of stock coverage for every period displayed.
  • Customer worked with two planning modes: the real-time mode, like MD04 with the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation, and the fix-photo mode, similar to MD05 (MRP-List) with a snapshot at the beginning of the day with the situation of initial stock, requirements and receipts.
  • Customer did not plan materials at MRP areas level.
  • Customer needed a more flexible material selection by using the typical grouping fields available on material master.
  • Customer needed a flexible visualization of quantities in several units of measure.

Customer requirement for MRP monitoring was to build a new collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials. On this tool, future requirements would be displayed together with historical data, thus allowing the customer to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period. Initial stock and final stock situation for every period based on total requirements and receipts were also required to be displayed.

Final decision was to create two similar planning monitoring tools: one focused on MPS products, the MPS Production Planning Monitor, and other focused on MRP products, the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor. On this blog post we will focus on the MPS Production Planning Monitor, which is described in detail down below. The MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor was already explained on previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results.

Figure 1: Material Scope for MRP Live run with MPS/MRP materials.

 

Production Planning Monitor MPS

The Production Planning Monitor MPS was intended for displaying the stock/requirements/receipts situation for a particular or a series of materials, from the point of view of final production, that is, the final product to sale. The prerequisite was the MRP Live (operative production plan MPS & MRP) previously executed for the corresponding plant, and this was automatically done daily at night by a background job.

The evaluations on this Monitor display all receipt and issue elements for the materials in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material, as well as to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements for this material. After a normal MPS&MRP run, the planner checks the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the materials, make necessary changes and ensures the availability of the materials for the next days, by creating production orders. The tool also allowed working by fixing the planning elements planned orders, but customer planners used to directly create the production orders.

As planners of this customer were old-school heavy users of SAP systems, this Monitor was developed in form of ALV list by using the BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST function.

 

Selection Screen for Production Planning Monitor MPS

The selection screen of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is displayed on below image (Figure 2):

Figure 2: Selection Screen of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

The period of time to be considered must be selected using the fields ‚ÄúDate From‚Äù and ‚ÄúDate To‚Äù. One week is proposed by default.

Requirements/receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field ‚ÄúPeriod Type‚Äù. The operative planning (short-term planning) is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.

The materials to be shown can be selected by material type, material group, MRP controller, production scheduler, and/or material code.

 

The default ‚ÄúPlanning Mode‚Äù is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (‚ÄúPlanning Fix-Photo‚Äù). Using this mode the entire requirements of the day and the entire production orders are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (‚ÄúPlanning Real-Time‚Äù). Using this other mode only the pending requirements of the day and the pending production orders are shown.

The quantities shown can be displayed on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user.

The total percentage of loss of the materials can be displayed as scrap (internal SAP), but also as drop or yield. This is just a percentage related to food processing to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The production orders can be splitted on daily production and pre-production quantities, by ticking the indicator ‚ÄúSplit Pre-Production‚Äù. This is just an option also related to food processing, to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The calculation of stock coverage on periods can be dynamically changed to consider or not the ‚Äú-Expired stock‚Äù and the ‚Äú+Production‚Äù.

Finally, consumption history can be shown together with MRP data, for 1 period only or for 4 periods.

 

Output List for Production Planning Monitor MPS

An example of the output list of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is displayed on below image (Figure 3):

Figure 3: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

This new monitoring tool allows to display at the same time the following data:

  • MPS planning results over sales & forecast (future).
  • Consumption history (past).

The MRP evaluation on this Monitor displays all receipt and issue elements for every material in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material. Moreover, for every period the historical consumption for the material is shown for the fourth previous periods, and also the average. This allows the planner to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period.

Requirements are shown in negative [- quantity] and receipts in positive [+ quantity], in order to ease the coverage understanding. A colour code red-yellow-green is used on field ‚ÄúStock Final‚Äù to easily identify stock breaks.

This new tool also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell.

The explanation of the meaning of the different columns of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is summarized on below image (Figure 4):

Figure 4: Explanation of the Columns of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

Displaying Options for Production Planning Monitor MPS

Requirements and receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field ‚ÄúPeriod Type‚Äù on the selection screen. The operative planning is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning is managed by week/month.

Figure 5: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool with Period Type by Week.

Figure 6: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool with Period Type by Month.

 

The monitor has an option for avoiding displaying empty lines, thus planner being able to only focus on periods containing data.

Figure 7: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool without empty lines.

 

The monitor also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell. The available screens for the data details are the following:

  • With double-click on the initial stock cell of the first period (current period), you navigate to detail stock list.
  • With double-click on the sales orders cell, you navigate to detail sales orders requirements list.
  • With double-click on the sales forecast cell, you navigate to detail sales forecast requirements list.
  • With double-click on any receipts cell (manufacturing orders), you navigate to detail receipts list.
  • With double-click on any consumption cell, you navigate to detail historical consumption list.

Figure 8: Detail Stock List when double-clicking on the initial stock cell of the first period

Figure 9: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on the Sales Orders cell

Figure 10: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on the Sales Forecast cell

Figure 11: Detail Receipts List with Production Orders when double-clicking on any receipt cell (internal procurement material)

Figure 12: Detail Historical Consumption List when double-clicking on any consumption cell

 

The production orders can be splitted on daily production and pre-production quantities, by ticking the indicator ‚ÄúSplit Pre-Production‚Äù. The concept of pre-production is something used on this plant to separate the production surplus of the previous day.

Figure 13: Output List of the Monitor with ‚ÄúSplit Pre-Production‚Äù option.

 

The monitor has two planning modes: the fix-photo mode and the real-time mode, similar to classic MRP List (static) and Stocks/Requirements List (dynamic). The default planning mode is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (‚ÄúPlanning Fix-Photo‚Äù). Using this mode, the entire requirements of the day and the entire receipts (manufacturing) are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (‚ÄúPlanning Real-Time‚Äù). Using this other mode, only the pending requirements of the day and the pending manufacturing orders are shown.

Figure 14: Output List of the Monitor for the different Planning Modes.

Figure 15: Output List with Details for the different Planning Modes.

 

The monitor can display the quantities on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user. This can be done either on the selection screen or directly on the main screen, as well as the planning mode.

Figure 16: Output List of the Monitor showing quantities in different units of measure.

 

Action Buttons for Production Planning Monitor MPS

The Monitor has an action button to create a new production order (transaction CO01). Furthermore, on the different screens with the details list of receipts, when clicking on the production order, the monitor navigates to the corresponding maintenance application (transaction CO02), where the user can directly edit the date and/or the quantity. This considerably improves the number of clicks required to perform those actions compared to use new modes.

Figure 17: Output List of the Monitor with the action button ‚ÄúCreate New Production Order‚Äù.

entry.title: Enhancing Flexible Workflows for Purchase Requisitions in SAP S/4HANA Based on Sum of All Line Items
entry.content:
Introduction
In today‚Äôs dynamic procurement environments, organizations need workflow mechanisms that intelligently adapt to business changes without adding unnecessary administrative overhead.
SAP S/4HANA‚Äôs Flexible Workflow framework provides this adaptability ‚Äî but sometimes, additional logic is required to differentiate approval levels based on the extent of change in a Purchase Requisition (PR).

This blog post explains how to extend the standard Flexible Workflow to trigger different approval levels depending on total PR price or amount variation.
The approach uses custom tables, BAdI implementations, and ABAP classes to intelligently decide when a workflow should restart ‚Äî either with single-level or multi-level approval. 

Business Requirement

The requirement is to handle changes to a Purchase Requisition (PR) that has already been released. Depending on how much the PR value changes (Total/Sum of all line items), the workflow should determine whether to restart as a single-step or multi-step approval process.

Scenario Price / Amount Change Approval Behavior

Minor Change0.01% ‚Äì 5% or Amount ‚â§ 25,000Trigger Single-Level approval
Major Change‚â• 5% or Amount > 25,000Trigger All Levels (Standard)

This design ensures minor updates don‚Äôt require multiple approvals, while significant changes trigger the full approval chain.

Solution Overview

To achieve this dynamic behavior, we implemented the following components:

  1. Custom Table (ZTPMM_PR_LOG) ‚Äì Stores workflow flag conditions (X or N).
  2. Custom Class (ZCL_PMM_PR_REL_STATUS) ‚Äì Determines PR change type using change logs (CDHDR, CDPOS).
  3. BAdI Implementation (MM_PUR_S4_PR_WFL_RESTART) ‚Äì Evaluates restart logic for Flexible Workflow.
  4. Condition Evaluation Class (ZCL_IM_PMM_WF_CONDITION_IMP) ‚Äì Validates workflow start conditions.

 

Workflow Flow Diagram

Below diagram shows the complete flow of logic ‚Äî from PR creation/change through workflow triggering.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Custom Table ‚Äì ZTPMM_PR_LOG

We created a custom transparent table ZTPMM_PR_LOG to store workflow type flags and PR numbers.
This table acts as a control mechanism for determining workflow behavior.

Table Fields

Field Key Data Element Description

MANDT‚úîMANDTClient
BANFN‚úîBANFNPurchase Requisition Number
WFTYP ZDE_PMM_WFTYPWorkflow Type (X = Single, N = Multi)

 

Determining Change Type ‚Äì Class ZCL_PMM_PR_REL_STATUS

This class identifies change details from PR change logs (CDHDR, CDPOS) to determine whether a modification is significant.
It compares previous vs current values and calculates the percentage difference.
If the difference falls within or exceeds defined thresholds, it updates ZTPMM_PR_LOG accordingly.

*--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
* Class Name:  ZCL_PMM_PR_REL_STATUS
* Author : Shravankumar Tiwari
* PR Approval Workflow - Get PR status single or Multi level flag
* im_ebeln = importing parameter in class
*--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  METHOD get_pr_status.

    CONSTANTS :
      lc_objectclas     TYPE cdhdr-objectclas VALUE 'BANF',
      lc_tabname_eban   TYPE cdpos-tabname VALUE 'EBAN',
      lc_fname_frgzu    TYPE cdpos-fname VALUE 'FRGZU',
      lc_chngind_u      TYPE cdpos-chngind VALUE 'U'.


    TYPES: BEGIN OF lty_cdchange,
             mandant    TYPE cdpos-mandant,
             objectclas TYPE cdpos-objectclas,
             objectid   TYPE cdpos-objectid,
             changenr   TYPE cdpos-changenr,
             tabkey     TYPE cdpos-tabkey,
             fname      TYPE cdpos-fname,
             chngind    TYPE cdpos-chngind,
             value_old  TYPE cdpos-value_old,
             value_new  TYPE cdpos-value_new,
             username   TYPE cdhdr-username,
             udate      TYPE cdhdr-udate,
             utime      TYPE cdhdr-utime,
             tcode      TYPE cdhdr-tcode,
           END OF lty_cdchange.

    DATA: lt_cdpos     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF lty_cdchange,
          lt_cdhdr_top TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF cdhdr,
          lt_cdpos_raw TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF cdpos,
          lv_purchaser TYPE ebeln.

    " Step 1: Get last 2 entries from CDHDR
    SELECT * FROM cdhdr
      INTO TABLE lt_cdhdr_top
     WHERE objectclas = lc_objectclas
       AND objectid   = im_ebeln 
     ORDER BY udate DESCENDING, utime DESCENDING
     .

    SORT lt_cdhdr_top BY udate DESCENDING utime DESCENDING.
    DELETE lt_cdhdr_top FROM 3.   " keep only the first 2 rows

    " Step 2: Get CDPOS entries that match CHANGENR from the above
    LOOP AT lt_cdhdr_top INTO DATA(ls_cdhdr).
      SELECT * FROM cdpos
        INTO TABLE lt_cdpos_raw                         "#EC CI_NOORDER
       WHERE objectclas = ls_cdhdr-objectclas
         AND objectid   = ls_cdhdr-objectid
         AND changenr   = ls_cdhdr-changenr
         AND tabname    = lc_tabname_eban
         AND fname      = lc_fname_frgzu
         AND chngind    = lc_chngind_u .

      LOOP AT lt_cdpos_raw INTO DATA(ls_pos).
        APPEND VALUE lty_cdchange(
          mandant     = ls_pos-mandant
          objectclas  = ls_pos-objectclas
          objectid    = ls_pos-objectid
          changenr    = ls_pos-changenr
          tabkey      = ls_pos-tabkey
          fname       = ls_pos-fname
          chngind     = ls_pos-chngind
          value_old   = ls_pos-value_old
          value_new   = ls_pos-value_new
          username    = ls_cdhdr-username
          udate       = ls_cdhdr-udate
          utime       = ls_cdhdr-utime
          tcode       = ls_cdhdr-tcode
        ) TO lt_cdpos.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.

**addional check for change case
    SELECT SINGLE *
      FROM ztpmm_pr_log
      INTO (ls_ztpmm_pr_log)
      WHERE banfn = im_ebeln.

    """Validate the records
    READ TABLE lt_cdpos INTO DATA(ls_cfpos1) INDEX 1. "Latest record
    DELETE lt_cdpos WHERE tabkey NE ls_cfpos1-tabkey.     
    READ TABLE lt_cdpos INTO DATA(ls_cfpos2) INDEX 2. "Old record
    IF  ls_cfpos1-value_old IS NOT INITIAL AND ls_cfpos2-value_new IS NOT INITIAL
      AND ls_ztpmm_pr_log-wftyp  = wc_x.
      ex_flag = wc_x. "single level
    ELSE.
      ex_flag = wc_n. "Multiple level
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

üí°Tip: The same logic can be extended for other purchasing documents like Purchase Orders (POs).

Restart Logic ‚Äì BAdI Implementation  

We used BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PR_WFL_RESTART to define the restart conditions for Flexible Workflow.
The following ABAP logic automatically determines if the workflow should restart as single-level (X) or multi-level (N).

(Notes :

  1. Variable lv_curr_total_value and lv_prev_total_value we need to sum all PR line items price from purchasereqitemscure and purchasereqitemsprev. We can create new static attribute table in class and fill information e.g. gt_purchasereqitemscurr and gt_purchasereqitemsprev  global table name
  2. Function module - ZFMPMM_RFC_PR_WF_ZUPD is remote enabled FM we update ztpmm_pr_log custom table from structure ls_ztpmm_pr_log )

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
"*  Custom Logic for Restarting Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisition
"*  Author : Shravankumar Tiwari
"*  Description : Determines workflow restart logic based on price
"*                 or amount change thresholds (minor vs major)
"--------------------------------------------------------------------

CONSTANTS : 
  lc_x       TYPE wfl_restart VALUE  'X',
  lc_plus_5  TYPE p DECIMALS 2 VALUE '5',
  lc_plus_01 TYPE p DECIMALS 2 VALUE '0.01',           
  lc_rfc     TYPE rfcdest  VALUE 'NONE'.

DATA :
  lv_item_value       TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_prev_total_value TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_curr_total_value TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_diff             TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_percent          TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log     TYPE ztpmm_pr_log, 
  lv_flag             TYPE abap_bool.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
" Calculate % difference between old and new PR values
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
lv_diff = lv_curr_total_value - lv_prev_total_value.
lv_percent = ( lv_diff / lv_prev_total_value ) * 100.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
" Check if difference exceeds thresholds (>5% or >25,000)
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
IF lv_percent > lc_plus_5 OR lv_diff > 25000.        
  lv_flag = abap_true.
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-banfn = purchasereqitemscurr-purchaserequisition.
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-wftyp = wc_n. "Multiple level
ENDIF.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
" Check for minor changes (0.01%‚Äì4.99% or ‚â§25,000) ‚Üí Single level
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
IF lv_flag = abap_false AND
  ( ( lv_percent BETWEEN lc_plus_01 AND lc_plus_5 ) OR
    ( lv_diff BETWEEN lc_plus_01 AND 25000 ) ).
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-banfn = purchasereqitemscurr-purchaserequisition.
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-wftyp = wc_x. "X = Single level
  lv_flag = abap_true.
ENDIF.

"-------------------------------------------------------------------- 
" Trigger restart if major change detected
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
IF lv_flag = abap_true.
  restartworkflow = lc_x.
  "Store WF indicator for PR: X = Single, N = Multiple
  CALL FUNCTION 'ZFMPMM_RFC_PR_WF_ZUPD' DESTINATION lc_rfc  
    EXPORTING
      im_ztpmm_pr_log = ls_ztpmm_pr_log.
ENDIF.

Logic Summary

Condition Workflow Type Approval Level

> 5% or > 25,000NMulti-Level
0.01%‚Äì4.99% or ‚â§ 25,000XSingle-Level

 

Workflow Start Condition ‚Äì Fiori Configuration

We configured two Flexible Workflow variants in the Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions‚Äù, each linked to a specific start condition based on the ZTPMM_PR_LOG flag.

Single-Level Approval (Flag ‚ÄòX‚Äô)

Triggers a single-step approval when the Creation Indicator = ‚ÄòX‚Äô.

Multi-Level Approval (Flag ‚ÄòN‚Äô)

Triggers three sequential approvals (Procurement, Project Control, Budget Owner) when the Creation Indicator = ‚ÄòN‚Äô.

Conditional Evaluation ‚Äì Dynamic Workflow Trigger

In the method IF_SWF_FLEX_IFS_CONDITION_EVAL~EVALUATE_CONDITION of class
ZCL_IM_PMM_WF_CONDITION_IMP, we dynamically evaluate workflow start parameters to determine if the condition should be true.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
"  **Author : Shravankumar Tiwari
" Conditional Evaluation ‚Äì Dynamic Workflow Trigger
"--------------------------------------------------------------------

METHOD if_swf_flex_ifs_condition_eval~evaluate_condition.
  LOOP AT it_parameter_value INTO ls_param_value.
    CASE ls_param_value-name.
      WHEN 'CreationIndicator'.
        READ TABLE lt_purchaserequisition INTO DATA(ls_purreq) INDEX 1.

        zcl_pmm_pr_rel_status=>get_pr_status(
          EXPORTING im_ebeln = ls_purreq-purchaserequisition
          IMPORTING ex_flag  = lv_flag_2
        ).

        IF ls_param_value-value EQ lv_flag_2.
          cv_is_true = abap_true.
        ELSE.
          cv_is_true = abap_false.
        ENDIF.

      WHEN OTHERS.
        cv_is_true = abap_false.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDMETHOD.

Key Benefits

‚úÖEfficiency ‚Äì Avoid redundant approvals for minor PR changes
‚úÖScalability ‚Äì Extendable to other workflow objects
‚úÖTransparency ‚Äì Logs stored in ZTPMM_PR_LOG
‚úÖUser-Friendly ‚Äì Maintained via Fiori, no coding required

Conclusion:  This enhancement enables organizations to make their SAP S/4HANA Flexible Workflow truly adaptive and business-aware.
By combining custom ABAP logic, Fiori configuration, and workflow extensibility, we achieve a balanced approach to automation and control. 

Thank you for learning.

entry.title: Implementing SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management ‚Äì Part 2 (Technical Deep Dive)
entry.content:
In Part 1, of this series, we explored how SAP‚ÄØEmarsys‚ÄØLoyalty‚ÄØManagement addresses modern‚Äêloyalty demands by going far beyond traditional point-schemes. We reviewed how loyalty programs are evolving into personalised, omnichannel experiences‚Äîand how Emarsys enables brands to design tiers, define actions and rewards, unify customer profiles across touchpoints, and engage members through highly relevant communications.

With that foundational business and functional outlook established, this article now moves into the technical implementation journey, explaining how the architecture, integrations and processes come together to make these business capabilities operational.

 

Prerequisites

To successfully implement SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management, ensure the following components and configurations are in place across the connected SAP landscape.

  SAP Emarsys and Loyalty

  • Unique Identifier for contacts
  • Smart Insight setup
  • Automation program to create and assign Loyalty HashID
  • Loyalty plan configuration (tiers, actions, and benefits)
  • Voucher setup (optional)
  • Loyalty Wallet (standard SDK-based or custom via Loyalty APIs)
  • Automation program to trigger Webhook on loyalty point confirmation events

   SAP S/4HANA

  • Sales data posting integration
  • GL accounts and controlling objects
  • Settlement and clearing logic
  • REST APIs for financial posting for the accruals and redemption scenario

 

Technical Architecture

 

 

Customer Registration and Loyalty Onboarding

Customer registration and loyalty onboarding begin when users join the program to enjoy rewards from their purchases and activities.
New customers can enrol during registration, while existing customers can join the program anytime. For both scenarios, a unique HashID must be generated and assigned to their record before enrolment.

The onboarding process can be initiated across mobile apps, websites, or POS systems.

Typically, SAP Sales Cloud or SAP S/4HANA act as the primary sources of customer data, which are then replicated to SAP Emarsys via SAP CPI.

When a new contact is registered, the record is first created in Sales Cloud or S/4HANA and then replicated to Emarsys. Once created, an automation program generates a HashID and stores it in a custom field at the contact level. Afterward, a Join API call is triggered to add the contact to the relevant Loyalty Plan.

For existing customers who join the loyalty program later, ensure that their HashID is already generated before executing the Join API call.

 

 

Points Accrual

The points accrual process enables customers to earn loyalty points and benefits based on their purchases and other qualifying activities. For purchase-based accruals, sales data flows from SAP S/4HANA (or ERP) to Smart Insight and then to Emarsys Loyalty, where points and benefits are automatically calculated according to the customer‚Äôs plan and tier.

Once points are confirmed, they are sent back to SAP S/4HANA for financial posting, ensuring accounting accuracy.

S/4HANA periodically sends sales transaction data to Emarsys through a tenant-specific Sales Data Load URL found under Predict ‚Üí Data Sources ‚Üí Sales Data in Emarsys. Once Emarsys receives the data, it calculates points based on the predefined logic.

An automation program triggers a webhook on the loyalty_points_from_purchase_confirmed event, which calls a CPI endpoint. This endpoint posts accrual entries in SAP S/4HANA, crediting customer accounts and updating liability GLs as per company-specific financial configurations.

 

 

Points Redemption

At checkout, customers can redeem their earned loyalty points either by paying directly with points or by using a voucher. Redemption can be initiated via mobile apps or websites during a purchase.

If the customer chooses to pay directly with points, the Remove Points API is called to deduct the required amount from their balance. A ‚ÄúPoints Removed‚Äù activity is automatically recorded in their Emarsys profile.

Alternatively, customers can claim a voucher using the Claim Voucher API. Once the voucher code is generated, it can be applied at checkout. When a voucher is redeemed, the equivalent points are deducted, and a ‚ÄúPoints Redeemed‚Äù activity is logged in Emarsys.

The financial postings for redemptions are handled by the respective sales channel (web, mobile, or POS) and then pushed to SAP S/4HANA via CPI to ensure accurate accounting entries.

 

 

Loyalty Segmentation, Personalization, and Campaigns

Effective segmentation and personalization are key to increasing engagement and retention. SAP Emarsys enables marketers to create segments using relational data templates, combining loyalty attributes (tier, points, activity type, or benefits) with contact and behavioral data.

The relational data connection can be setup easily by referring the help link ‚Äú Setting up Loyalty RDS connection‚Äù and templates can be setup as mentioned in the link  ‚Äú Setting up Loyalty segment templates‚Äù

These segments can be used across multiple campaign channels, including email, SMS, push, and web. Personalization tokens dynamically adapt campaign messages to show details such as the customer‚Äôs name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone.

 

  Personalization and Campaign Execution

  Once segments are built, they can be used across multiple channels ‚Äî email, SMS, push notifications, or web campaigns.
  Using personalization tokens, each campaign message can dynamically adapt to display the customer‚Äôs name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone, delivering a truly personalized experience.

  SAP Emarsys offers prebuilt email template blocks designed for loyalty-related communications. Upon activation of a loyalty plan, the system automatically generates the relevant loyalty tokens. Furthermore, whenever a new Action or voucher is created, corresponding personalization tokens are generated by default.

  By blending loyalty data with Emarsys campaign automation, businesses can drive:

  • Higher engagement through relevant messaging
  • Increased redemption and repeat purchase rates
  • Stronger customer retention and satisfaction
     

 

 

Loyalty Reports and Dashboards

Analytics play a critical role in measuring loyalty program performance. SAP Emarsys publishes loyalty data to Google Cloud Platform through Open Data Views. These can be connected to SAP Datasphere using the Remote Table option for near real-time data access.

Within SAP Datasphere, organizations can model data, define KPIs (such as Total Points Accrued vs. Redeemed or Active Members by Tier), and then visualize insights using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) dashboards.

This seamless data flow ‚Äî from Emarsys to GCP, Datasphere, and SAC ‚Äî provides real-time visibility into loyalty KPIs, helping businesses make data-driven decisions and optimize customer engagement strategies.

 

References:

  • List of All Public API Endpoints
  • Smart Insight Settings
  • Loyalty Implementation & Activation
  • Loyalty Tactics
  • Relational Data
  • Creating Segments
  • Personalization
  • Automation Programs

 

Summary

In Part 2, we explored the technical implementation journey of SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management ‚Äî covering end-to-end integration, automation flows, financial postings, customer service enablement, campaign personalization, and analytical insights through SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud.

Stay tuned for Part 3, where we will focus on Customer Service and Support Scenarios in greater detail.

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (1/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP standard production orders information system, the COOIS transaction, is a very powerful and flexible tool to report various aspects of production and planned orders. It can be easily customized and enhanced.

The COHV transaction couples COOIS with order mass processing functions enhancing the PP information system even further. It provides various mass processing functions like order release, staging, costing, etc.

The note 1819470 - Mass processing functions are missing in t-code COHV has introduced two additional options to fix/delete fixing and to delete planned orders. The note shows that the mass processing capabilities of COHV can be enhanced. However, I have not been able to find any official extension points or documentation on how to add customer defined functions to COHV. This article is meant to close this gap and to present step-by-step instructions to implement new mass processing functions.

 

Enhance fixed values list of CO_FUNCT domain

The mass processing function list is defined with a reference to CO_FUNCT data element.

Figure 1: Technical details of the "Function" field in COHV

The data element refers to the CO_FUNCT domain.

Figure 2: The CO_FUNCT data element details

The list of mass processing functions available in COHV is defined with fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain. Notice that the list has already been enhanced with 205 and 215 functions delivered with the note 1819470 - Mass processing functions are missing in t-code COHV

Figure 3: The fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain

Therefore, the first step is to add a custom function code to the fixed values of the domain. The exact procedure is described on SAP Help: Creating Fixed Value Appends 

Figure 4: The fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain enhanced with a custom function

 

Register the custom function

The next step is to register the custom function with COHV. That is done in the include LCOWORKF06, the FORM routine REGISTERED_FUNCTIONS_INIT

SAP provides the enhancement spot ES_SAPLCOWORK to register additional functions. However, it is for SAP internal use only. Unfortunately, there are no standard enhancements available here either. Therefore, I am going to use implicit enhancement at the end of the routine.

The fct_icon field is optional, but it is a nice touch to have an icon assigned to the mass processing function.

 

Add the custom function in the COISL transaction

Finally, the custom function needs to be assigned to order information list type in the COISL transaction.

 

Final result

The final result is that the custom function is visible and selectable in COHV.

Figure 5: The custom function in the COHV initial screen

 It is also available as a push button with the icon assigned in the registration step in the COHV toolbar.

Figure 6: The custom function in the COHV toolbar

The custom function is also visible and executable from the COHV results list. 

Naturally, the custom function does not do anything for now. The function execution implementation is the topic of the next episode. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

entry.title: Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario
entry.content:
If your SAP ERP system has been running for an extended period, your database has probably grown several terabytes in size. This presents a double challenge: managing such a large volume of data is complex, and transitioning to SAP S/4HANA can lead to significant downtime. 

To unlock the digital transformation capabilities of the SAP Business Transformation Center (for more information, see [Everything about using SAP Business Transformation center for SDT S/4 HANA Conversion 2023 from ECC]), your target system needs to be manually prepared, as explained in [Creating the Shell System for SAP Business Transformation Center: A Practical Approach].  

If these challenges sound familiar, you‚Äôre in the right place! 

With Support Package 45 (SP45) of Software Provisioning Manager 1.0, a new scenario called "Shell Copy‚Äù is now available. Similar to the traditional ‚ÄúSystem Copy‚Äù process - where you use Software Provisioning Manager to copy or migrate an existing SAP ABAP system, the Shell Copy assists in system copying, but with one key difference: it significantly reduces the volume of your new target database. 

The Shell Copy scenario keeps the skeleton of your system, along with all your custom configurations and developments, such as cross-client customizing, dictionary, and repository data, while leaving out the application data (see item 1 in the diagram below). 

If needed, after performing a shell copy, you can use remote client copy (using the SAP_UCSV profile) for all clients except 000 (see item 2 in the diagram below).   A remote client copy for client 000 is not required as this is delivered during the Shell Copy process.

 

In numbers, the SAP tables DD002L, DD003L, REPOSRC, and SEOCLASS, which are part of the SAP system and contain important metadata, remain the same in both the source system and the target system. However, another table, AFPO, which contains application-specific data, is truncated: 

 

Source: Ôøº  Target: 
 

When we tested the Shell Copy scenario on our own small production system, we saw a significant drop in the volume size of the database: 

 Source: Target: 
 

We expect that the reduction ratio will vary a lot based on how much application data your SAP system contains. At the time of the blog post, the Shell Copy scenario is only available through the product provisioning functionality for ‚ÄòEHP8 of SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP‚Äô: 

 

The Shell Copy scenario is a homogeneous process, which means it works with the same type of database on both the source and target systems. It supports SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE), Oracle, MS SQL Server, and IBM Db2 for Linux, UNIX and Windows.  

Another key difference from the traditional System Copy is that Shell Copy uses a more advanced migration tool called the Database Migration Option (DMO) in Software Update Manager (SUM) 2.0, instead of the old migration monitor. 

Thanks to the features of SUM DMO, the Shell Copy process is not only more efficient, but also reduces the overall downtime. For example, the export takes place online with a manageable number of R3load jobs, so you don‚Äôt have to shut down the running SAP system during the Shell Copy process.  To ensure smooth operation of the productive processes, we recommend that you schedule the export in times of reduced workload.

I am going to copy the function group COWORK170 to a custom function group and implement the custom mass processing logic there. Before that, let us execute a couple of preliminary steps.

I am trying to keep to SAP naming convention throughout all the subsequent steps.

 

Dialog structure creation

Copy the COWORK170_SETUP structure to ZCOWORK999_SETUP with SE11.

 

Function group ZCOWB999 creation

 

Function group ZCOWB999 adjustments

Now we need to scan the ZCOWB999 function group and replace all the artifacts of the standard COWB170 function group with our custom objects:

Find object‚Ä¶Replace with object‚Ä¶
CO_WORK170_CREATEZ_CO_WORK999_CREATE
CO_WORK170_DELETE<Z_CO_WORK999_DELETE
CO_WORK170_EXEC_SINGLEZ_CO_WORK999_EXEC_SINGLE
CO_WORK170_INITIALIZE_EXECZ_CO_WORK999_INITIALIZE_EXEC
CO_WORK170_SAVEZ_CO_WORK999_SAVE
CO_WORK170_SETUP_PAIZ_CO_WORK999_SETUP_PAI
CO_WORK170_SETUP_PBOZ_CO_WORK999_SETUP_PBO
CO_WORK170_UPDATE_INTERNZ_CO_WORK999_UPDATE_INTERN
COWORK170_SETUPZCOWORK999_SETUP

The easiest way to do that is to search for the source code of the ZCOWB999 function group for WORK170 string.

Here are my changes:

 

Custom processing logic

Let us replace that with same trivial test custom logic:

entry.title: Where to begin with SAP Requirements in Jira?
entry.content:
I think all of SAP project experts will agree that SAP Requirements Management is much more than an Excel file downloaded from the SAP Activate Roadmap accelerators list and filled with unstructured notes from Fit-2-Standard workshops. In practice, Requirements Management should be the bridge between business intent and tested, working functionality. And yet, this bridge often does not exist. The disconnect between what business processes should do and what finally goes live remains one of the biggest causes of rework and missed value in SAP programs.

Why managing requirements is important?

A weak requirements discipline leads later to solution scope creep, fragmented testing, and the famous ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt what we expected‚Äù moment during the UAT. Well organized requirements management turns conversations into commitments - every requirement becomes traceable from the "Need" through "Realize and Test" to "Deploy". Traceability is the essence of governance in SAP Activate.

High-level business outcomes are defined during Discover and Prepare phase, while detailed functional, non-functional, and delta requirements are refined and documented during the Explore phase. They are documented against SAP Best Practice processes (for example BD9 - Sell from Stock).

Every requirement should be linked to its related Test Case and Work Package to ensure full traceability from Fit-to-Standard through Deployment. This linkage keeps it transparent, testable, and aligned with business value.

How SAP Activate Defines a Requirement

In the Requirements-to-Deploy (R2D) framework, a requirement is a single, testable statement describing the system behavior or capability needed to fulfill a business need.
Each requirement should be:
1) Atomic ‚Äì one clear need, not a bundle of ideas.
2) Unambiguous ‚Äì can be interpreted only in one way.
3) Traceable ‚Äì linked to a Process, Scope Item and Work Package (deliverable).
4) Testable ‚Äì verifiable through objective criteria.

A requirement is not a meeting note like ‚ÄòNeed better reports‚Äô; it states precisely what the system must do. It defines what the system must achieve but not yet how to implement it.

When written in a standardized way, requirements become the shared language between Business and IT - the foundation for alignment, testing, and auditability.

 Practically in Jira

Ok, so if it is now clear what a requirement is and how it should be defined, the next question becomes where to manage all this effectively. That‚Äôs where Jira - when properly configured - becomes a practical backbone for collecting, tracking, and approving SAP requirements.

In Jira, requirements can be managed as custom Work Item types aligned with SAP Activate governance standards.

  1. Create a dedicated work item type called Requirement with a distinct icon.

  2. Configure essential fields and workflow statuses (e.g., Draft ‚Üí To Be Approved ‚Üí Approved ‚Üí In Realization ‚Üí Completed).

  3. Link each requirement to its Scope item, ensuring full traceability.

Once configured, you can collect requirements directly in Jira during your Fit-To-Standard workshops.

SAP native tools

While SAP Cloud ALM and Solution Manager‚Äôs Focused Build provide strong governance for requirement-to-deploy processes, many organizations still complement them with Jira to enable broader Agile methods delivery, integrate non-SAP workstreams, and leverage its native links with Confluence and Test automation tools. Also, there are a few integration tools available that allow for data exchange between Jira and SAP.

Your Goal

In any SAP project, your goal is to ensure that every piece of delivered and tested functionality traces back to at least one well-written requirement. However, the discipline lies not in the tool itself but in the governance structure and consistency with which it‚Äôs used.

This will encourage me to write more articles in SAP Community. Thank you!

Bogdan G√≥rka works as Atlassian Solution Architect and SAP Project Governance Consultant.
Creator of R2D ALM for Jira, independent Atlassian consultant, and founder of PMBG.EU.

entry.title: How to turn SAP workshop notes into clear and testable Requirements
entry.content:
During SAP Activate‚Äôs Explore phase and the Fit-to-Standard workshops, consultants capture dozens of ‚Äúrequirements,‚Äù each meant to articulate a specific business need. Without clear formulation standards, a few weeks later no one is quite sure what the original request actually meant. This undermines the workshop‚Äôs primary goal: validating solution fit.

The real pain - inconsistency

In SAP programs, requirements that are vague or inconsistently written become a main source of unnecessarily lost effort. When two workstreams describe the same business need in different words, duplication multiply which may lead to unnecessary testing of the same functionality or cause change requests.

For example, when a requirement says ‚Äúsystem should support automatic approval‚Äù no one will know what support actually meant when they discussed it during a workshop. You cannot test such a requirement later.

Ambiguity has measurable cost

Each unclear requirement multiplies into unnecessary discussions, rework, and test defects. Misunderstandings accumulate silently until they become visible during the first cycle of testing, when the system finally reveals whether the requirement was truly met.

The true risk of Requirements Management is not the absence of requirements documentation, but the lack of consistency in how requirements are formulated.

Not having the requirement formulation standards, which are recommended by SAP Activate, is one of the major sources of rework and wasted effort. When requirements are written in different formats and tones, they cannot be easily classified, compared, or reused.

Why clear formulation matters

SAP Activate‚Äôs agile approach is built on the idea that requirements evolve. But they must be clear right from the start as the backlog entry, so that they can be reviewed, classified, and approved later. Clarity does not mean rigidity. It means writing requirements so they can be discussed, prioritized, tested, and traced - even as they may change later.

 A well formulated requirement contains four elements in one short sentence:

Who ‚Äì the role that needs the functionality
When ‚Äì the situation or trigger
What ‚Äì the action or system behavior
Why ‚Äì the intended business benefit

When these four parts are present, the requirement becomes verifiable. It can be confirmed during testing and explained during audit reviews. More importantly, it can be reused across teams and releases because it is self-contained and unambiguous.

The right format for SAP projects

SAP‚Äôs Agile method proposes the familiar User Story format: ‚ÄúAs a [role], I want [feature], so that [business value].‚Äù In practice, this structure is often too generic for configuration and testing.

A better pattern for SAP requirements adds context and system behavior:

As [Role], when [Condition], the system will [Action] on [Object] so that [Benefit].

This sentence looks simple, but it solves three common problems:

1) It describes the trigger (when), which links to a real process step.
2) It defines the system reaction (will [Action]), which makes the behavior testable.
3) It keeps the business benefit explicit, which ties it back to value and approval.

This version includes all four elements: who, when, what, and why.
Anyone reading it should understands both the intent and the expected outcome.

Adding a ‚ÄúHow to Demo‚Äù section

A practical way to make requirements even clearer is to include a short ‚ÄúHow to Demo‚Äù note directly under the description. This is not a full test case but rather a quick outline of how someone would prove that the requirement works. This serves as a draft for formal test cases and ensures that requirements can be verified during Activate‚Äôs test preparation phase.

This small ‚ÄúHow to demo‚Äù section acts as an early test-case draft. It helps reviewers visualize expected behavior and gives testers a ready starting point for building the formal Test Case later. In larger projects, these demo notes become a lightweight bridge between requirement authoring and structured testing, keeping intent, behavior, and verification tightly connected.

Finding the right level of detail

A well-written requirement should guide the Realize phase. Too much detail turns it into a mini-functional specification; too little makes it meaningless. The right level of abstraction sits between business intention and technical configuration.

When many team members are involved in requirements formulation, duplication can easily occur. Similar needs appear in different modules, often under different wording. To prevent this, each requirement should reference its related SAP Best Practice Process represented by an approved Scope Item. This simple linking helps identify overlaps early and supports reuse across workstreams.

From quick notes to refined requirements

In line with SAP Activate‚Äôs iterative principle, requirements may first be recorded in simple terms and refined later during backlog reviews and work package definition. What matters most in that moment is to capture the intent in a simplified form and then refine it later.

For example:
‚ÄúAdd a process step for automatic credit check approval before delivery creation.‚Äù ‚Üí GAP

Such a note still has value. During later review, typically when preparing the related Work Package, the requirement can be reformulated to the full standard:

As a Sales Manager, when a sales order is saved and the customer exceeds the credit limit, the system will block delivery creation on the delivery document so that only approved orders can ship.

This two-step approach keeps workshops efficient while ensuring that every requirement ultimately meets the agreed structure before review, approval, and test preparation.

How to make this standard work in Jira?

Formulation discipline is easier to maintain when supported by a tool.
In Jira, you can create an automation rule that pre-populates the Description field of each new Requirement with a Activate-style structured template.

In the template, you can use a table to make the content easier to follow. Each author then only needs to fill in the blanks. This keeps every requirement standardized.

For simplicity, below the requirement you can add a simple list with the ‚ÄòHow to demo‚Äô steps.

Why it‚Äôs worth the effort?

A requirement is not a transcript of a workshop discussion. It is a helpful SAP governance standard that supports the SAP delivery lifecycle.

Teams that adopt this standardization rule quickly notice tangible benefits:
-> Requirements become easier to review and approve.
-> Test cases can be linked directly and generated faster.
-> Cross-team understanding improves, because every sentence follows the same logic.

Formulation discipline may feel like a big effort, but it pays back throughout the project lifecycle. Clear requirements accelerate testing, improve governance, and reduce rework.

entry.title: Building Bridges Between SAP and Databricks: A Dream Team for Your Data and AI-Powered Analytics
entry.content:
The Interplay of SAP & Databricks: Why Now?

The combination of SAP and Databricks is more than just a technical integration; it is a strategic course-setting. It brings together the best of two worlds:

  • SAP as a Stable Foundation: Your SAP systems contain the most important business data‚Äîfrom financial key figures to master data. This data is not only comprehensive but also semantic and contextual, making it an ideal basis for training AI models.
  • Databricks as an Innovation Engine: Databricks offers a scalable platform for Data, Analytics, and AI. It is a powerful engine for machine learning and complex analyses, enabling companies to gain valuable insights from large amounts of data.

This Dream Team transforms corporate management. Instead of merely answering questions like "What happened?", Business AI enables a look into the future: "Why did it happen?" and, most importantly, "What will happen and what should we do?".

Figure 1: Interplay of SAP & Databricks

 

The Benefits of Integration at a Glance

The partnership between SAP and Databricks offers tangible benefits that are evident at the strategic, technical, and operational levels.

Strategic Advantages

The integration ensures open data management and analytics for SAP and non-SAP data. Complete alignment with the SAP Business Data Cloud with strong governance creates a future-proof architecture. The simplified pricing model in general Capacity Units also makes the start easier to plan.

Technical Advantages

The platform is designed to allow extended use via interfaces and can scale with growing demands and data volumes. The seamless integration of the SAP Business Warehouse and SAP S/4HANA with data products enables an end-to-end process. An important difference when deciding for or against an SAP Databricks: The SAP Databricks is fully managed by SAP. This means it is technically operational immediately.

Operational Advantages

Companies benefit from a Hyperscaler infrastructure, which ensures resilience and a reduction in Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). Technical operation is supported by Managed Services from SAP, which reduces complexity in day-to-day business and allows for the installation of upgrades on demand.

How the Dream Team Works in Practice

Databricks offers a number of key elements to enable integration and analysis:

  • Unity Catalog: The Unity Catalog serves as a central landing zone for governance and data products. Metadata is managed here and the data is stored in Delta Tables, ensuring a consistent view of your information and secure access.

Figure 2: Databricks Unity Catalog: The landing zone for governance and data products.

  • Databricks Workspace: Modeling and development take place in the Databricks Workspace. Users work here with interactive notebooks, which offer an encapsulated programming interface for agile and flexible work. SQL, Python, R, and Scala are supported as languages.

Figure 3: Databricks Workspace: Modeling takes place in Databricks within the Workspace, using "Notebooks" among other tools.

  • Databricks Machine Learning: The integration of MLflow enables the training, versioning, and deployment of models. The clear management of training runs and the linking of datasets significantly simplifies the establishment of professional AI in the company. Important to know: The operation of Machine Learning models should strategically take place in SAP AI Core, although Databricks also supports this functionality depending on the use case.

Figure 4: Databricks Machine Learning. Model training (experiments), model versioning, or the deployment of models on one platform.

Conclusion: From Dataset to Smart Decision

The combination of SAP and Databricks elevates data analysis to a new level. Your financial key figures and master data serve as a reliable source for intelligent analyses. The integration with Databricks makes it possible to automatically recognize patterns and correlations from this data. The platform's flexibility and scalability allow complex AI models to be applied and the resulting cluster information seamlessly fed back into your SAP world to enable users to make well-founded decisions. The deep and exclusive technical integration of both worlds guarantees a secure and fast exchange of data products.

Key Takeaways for Your Company

  • Data and AI are moving closer together: The separation between data storage (SAP) and data analysis (Databricks) is a thing of the past. The seamless integration allows your most valuable business data to be used directly for modern AI applications. This creates a unified information base and eliminates fragmented data silos.
  • High Potential through Synergies: The combination of SAP‚Äôs standardized data storage and proven processes with Databricks‚Äô innovative AI technology opens up completely new possibilities. You can not only see what happened but also why it happened and what will happen next. This empowers you to act proactively and identify risks early on.
  • Professional AI Establishment: The Databricks platform offers a mature environment for professionally establishing AI applications in the company. Thanks to functions like Unity Catalog for data governance and Databricks Machine Learning for model training, you can ensure that your AI initiatives are scalable, secure, and sustainable.

How You Can Get Started Now: Our Practical Advice

Many companies hesitate to take the first step because the topic seems complex. However, getting started doesn't have to be overwhelming. We recommend starting with a Proof-of-Concept (PoC).

  • Define a Clear Use Case: Choose an area in your company where data analysis can bring real added value. This could be optimizing inventory management, predicting customer behavior, or automating financial forecasts.
  • Utilize Your Existing Potential: A PoC helps you assess how you can tap into your unused data potential. This provides concrete results and allows you to prove the business case for a broader implementation.
  • Start Small to Grow Big: Begin with a manageable project to achieve quick successes and build confidence in the new technology. The scalability of the platform allows you to easily add more use cases later.

The partnership between SAP and Databricks is not a futuristic concept but a practice-oriented solution that helps you make data-driven decisions and future-proof your company. The time to awaken your SAP data from its slumber is now.

Now it‚Äôs your turn: What experiences have you already had with using SAP data for intelligent analyses? What challenges do you see on the path to Business AI? We look forward to your perspectives and to shaping the future of data analysis together.

entry.title: SAP TechEd2025-XP264- Explore how to run cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Kyma runtime
entry.content:
Description

A sneak preview of the material for the SAP TechEd 2025 session catalog number XP264 - Explore how to run cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Kyma runtime.

  • Day-2 Operations: Management, Maintenance, Monitoring, and Optimization
  • Technical connectivity to public and private (on-premise) systems

The repository with the session material will be made available publicly on Monday, November 3rd.

See you there in Messe Berlin, Messedamm 22, 14055 Berlin, room 504, Hall 5.2, on November 06, 2025 09:00 AM CEST!

 

Overview

This session introduces attendees to Day-2 operations with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime - a managed kubernetes environment to help connect and extend enterprise applications in the cloud-native world.

In a nutshell, SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime (SKR) is a managed k8s runtime environment with a kubernetes cluster based on Gardener and a set of building blocks called Kyma modules.

Each instance of SAP BTP Kyma runtime environment is a single k8s gardener cluster with its own set of kyma modules.
Subsequently, all these clusters are managed by a central Kyma Control Plane (KCP) that orchestrates the lifecycle of

  • the underlying hyperscaler project,
  • the Gardener Cluster,
  • and the Kyma modules.

 

 

During the session you will learn

  • how to operate applications with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime and discover the power of smooth integration with cloud applications and on-premise systems using the advanced connectivity features.
  • to explore operational best practices from mastering troubleshooting techniques and intelligent root-cause analysis to event-driven autoscaling that adapts to your business needs in real time.
  • about BTP multitenant applications with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime.

Requirements

The requirements to follow the exercises in this repository are...

Important

  • You must be able to fork the repository and activate the github actions at the fork. This is mandatory for this session!
  • Thus, you may need a GitHub user.
    If you haven't got one yet, please sign-up on GitHub before the workshop or at the very beginning of the session.

Important

The session content is provided exclusively on the SAP-Samples github, and many excercises have been implemented as CI/CD Github Actions worflows (GHA).

Security is paramount. With the Github Action IDP-delegated flow, there is no more need to provide kubernetes and btp credentials when using github actions.

  • ‚úÖThe Github Action workflows acting as the OIDC provider.

  • ‚úÖAll the kubernetets environments in the landscape are configured to trust GitHub‚Äôs token identity provider. They come with the pre-configured OIDC applications leveraging the built-in Gardener OIDC shoot extension.

  • ‚úÖSAP Cloud Identity Services acting as a platform IDP on the BTP side of the house has been federated with the Github actions OIDC Provider

  • ‚úÖAs a result, the very short-lived credentials are being fetched and rotated automatically on the behalf of the repository user for both kubernetes and btp platform operations.

  • The good news is you may run the GHA-based exercises directly, from your forked repository, in a browser on the provided teched laptop.

Disclaimer

Personal devices should not be used for this session. Hands-on session participants will be using Windows laptops provided by the organizers.

What to expect from this session?

  • üëâRun and take time to inspect the results of the built-in automations. Ask questions. And if you feel like doing, go ahead and create your own variants as well.

  • üëâThe recommendation is, however, to go with the flow of the exercises, inspect the results, ask questions and leave the rest for the homework.

entry.title: SAP MDG: Locking Supplier General Data When Data Already exists
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great üôÇ

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.
Note 03: There are several ways to implement; this blog is written about one of them.

Create one custom class & redefine the standard class (CL_MDG_BS_ECC_HANDLER)

Method Responsible: IF_MDG_BS_BP_ACCESS_HANDLER~GET_ENTITY_PROPERTIES.

DATA: lv_crequest_type TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
      lv_cr_number     TYPE usmd_crequest,
      lo_app_context   TYPE REF TO if_usmd_app_context.

DATA: lo_data      TYPE REF TO data,
      lt_data      TYPE usmd_ts_data_entity,
      lt_msg       TYPE usmd_t_message,
      ls_msg       TYPE usmd_s_message,
      lt_erp_v     TYPE REF TO data.

FIELD-SYMBOLS:
      <lt_erpv> TYPE SORTED TABLE,
      <ls_erpv> TYPE any,
      <lv_erpv> TYPE any.

CALL METHOD cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context
  RECEIVING
    eo_context = lo_app_context.

IF lo_app_context IS BOUND.

  CALL METHOD lo_app_context->get_attributes
    IMPORTING
      ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
      ev_crequest_type = lv_crequest_type
      ev_process       = lv_process.

  lv_crequest_type = iv_crequest_type.

  CALL METHOD super->if_mdg_bs_bp_access_handler~get_entity_properties
    EXPORTING
      iv_entity         = iv_entity
      is_key            = is_key
      io_model          = io_model
      iv_crequest_type  = iv_crequest_type
      iv_crequest_step  = iv_crequest_step
      iv_crequest_index = iv_crequest_index
    CHANGING
      cf_read_only      = cf_read_only.

  IF iv_crequest_type EQ 'ZMDGS03'.
    io_model->read_entity_data_all(
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname      = 'BP_HEADER'
        if_active        = abap_false
        i_crequest       = lv_cr_number
      IMPORTING
        et_message       = lt_msg
        et_data_entity   = lt_data
    ).

    lt_erp_v = VALUE #(
      lt_data[ usmd_entity      = 'BP_HEADER'
               usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_VENGEN'
               struct           = 'KATTR' ]-r_t_data OPTIONAL ).

    IF lt_erp_v IS NOT INITIAL.
      IF iv_entity EQ 'BP_VENGEN'.
        cf_read_only = 'X'.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDIF.

SAP S/4HANA   SAP Master Data Governance   ABAP Development  

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
